articles.title: Distribution of Legislative Powers - Basic Framework

territorialExtent: **Art 245(1)**: Parliament can make laws for **whole or any part** of India
**Art 245(2)**: State Legislature can make laws for **whole or any part of that State**
**Extraterritorial operation**: Parliament can make laws with extraterritorial operation; State cannot (except in certain cases)
art246: **Art 246**: Distribution of legislative powers between Union and States
**Parliament**: Can legislate on **Union List + Concurrent List + Residuary subjects** (Art 246(1), (2))
**State Legislatures**: Can legislate on **State List + Concurrent List** (Art 246(3))
**Exclusive spheres**: Union List → Only Parliament; State List → Only State Legislature (except special circumstances)
constitutionalBasis: **7th Schedule**: Contains 3 Lists defining legislative competence
**Union List (List I)**: 97 subjects - Defence, Foreign affairs, Currency, Banking, Railways, etc.
**State List (List II)**: 61 subjects - Police, Public order, Agriculture, Land, Local govt, etc.
**Concurrent List (List III)**: 47 subjects - Criminal law, Marriage, Forests, Education, etc.
principleBehindDistribution: **National importance**: Union List (Defence, Foreign policy, Currency)
**Local importance**: State List (Police, Agriculture, Public health)
**Common interest**: Concurrent List (Criminal law, Marriage, Education)
**Economies of scale**: Union List (Railways, Posts, Atomic energy)
content.examTips: **Art 245-246**: Basic framework for legislative distribution. Parliament → Union + Concurrent + Residuary; States → State + Concurrent. **7th Schedule**: Union (97), State (61), Concurrent (47). Know major subjects in each list. Parliament has wider powers.

overview: **Exclusive domain**: Only **Parliament** can legislate on these subjects
**National importance**: Subjects requiring national uniformity and central control
**Residuary power**: Any subject not in any list → Union (Art 248)
majorSubjects: **1. Defence** (Entry 1) - Armed forces, deployment, war and peace
**2. Foreign Affairs** (Entry 10) - Diplomatic relations, UN, treaties, extradition
**7. Shipping** (Entry 24) - Ports, shipping on high seas, inland waterways
**8. Posts and Telegraphs** (Entry 31) - Post offices, telephones, wireless, broadcasting
**10. Foreign Trade** (Entry 41) - Import, export, inter-state trade and commerce
**14. Atomic Energy** (Entry 53) - Nuclear energy, radioactive substances
**15. Mines and Minerals** (Entry 54) - Petroleum, oilfields, mineral resources
**16. Elections** (Entry 72) - Elections to Parliament and State Legislatures
**17. Audit** (Entry 76) - CAG, audit of Union and State accounts
**19. Income Tax** (Entry 82) - Tax on income other than agricultural income
**21. Excise Duties** (Entry 84) - Except on alcoholic liquors
importantPoints: **Most important list**: Union has most powers; Shows strong Centre
**Taxation**: Major taxes (Income tax, Customs, Corporation tax, Excise, Service tax) in Union List
**Strategic subjects**: Defence, Foreign affairs, Currency, Atomic energy - Only Centre
**Economic control**: Banking, Insurance, Foreign trade, Currency - Centre controls economy
content.examTips: **Union List = 97 subjects**. Remember major ones: Defence, Foreign affairs, Railways, Currency, Banking, Atomic energy, Income tax, Customs, Corporation tax. Shows **strong Centre** (unitary feature). Only Parliament can legislate (except emergency).

overview: **Exclusive domain**: Only **State Legislatures** can legislate (normal circumstances)
**Local importance**: Subjects of local concern requiring regional knowledge
**But exceptions exist**: Parliament can legislate under special circumstances (Art 249, 250, 252, 356)
majorSubjects: **1. Public Order** (Entry 1) - BUT not including use of armed forces
**3. Administration of Justice** (Entry 3) - Courts except SC and HCs
**5. Local Government** (Entry 5) - Municipal corporations, panchayats, local bodies
**6. Public Health and Sanitation** (Entry 6) - Hospitals, sanitation
**7. Agriculture** (Entry 14) - Farming, crop production, pest control
**8. Land** (Entry 18) - Land revenue, rights in land, land tenure, transfer
**9. Forests** (Entry 17A - shifted to Concurrent List by 42nd Amendment 1976)
**11. Industries** (Entry 24) - Subject to Concurrent List (industries declared by Parliament)
**20. Land Revenue** (Entry 45) - Tax on agricultural land
**22. Estate Duty** (Entry 47) - Except on agricultural land
importantPoints: **61 subjects**: Originally 66; 5 shifted to Concurrent List (42nd Amendment 1976)
**Which 5 shifted?**: Education, Forests, Weights & Measures, Protection of wild animals, Administration of justice
**Local subjects**: Agriculture, Police, Public health, Land, Local govt
**Taxation**: Land revenue, Agricultural income, Excise on liquor, Property tax, Vehicle tax
**BUT Centre can invade**: During emergency, national interest, state consent, President's Rule
42ndAmendmentImpact: **5 subjects shifted from State to Concurrent List**:
4. **Protection of wild animals and birds** (Entry 17B → Concurrent Entry 17B)
5. **Administration of justice; constitution and organization of all courts except SC and HCs** (Entry 3 → Concurrent Entry 11A)
**Effect**: Centralization - Centre got power to legislate on these subjects
content.examTips: **State List = 61 subjects** (originally 66). Remember: Police, Public order, Agriculture, Land, Local govt, Public health. **42nd Amendment shifted 5 to Concurrent** (Education, Forests, Weights & Measures, Wild animals, Justice administration). Shows gradual **centralization**.

overview: **Joint domain**: **Both Parliament and State Legislatures** can legislate
**Conflict resolution**: If both legislate and conflict, **Union law prevails** (Art 254)
**State law can survive**: If President gives assent; But Parliament can override anytime
majorSubjects: **1. Criminal Law** (Entry 1) - IPC, CrPC (except police, public order)
**5. Marriage and Divorce** (Entry 5) - Marriage laws, divorce
**6. Transfer of Property** (Entry 6) - Property transfer, registration
**11. Administration of Justice** (Entry 11A - 42nd Amendment) - Subordinate courts
**13. Contempt of Court** (Entry 11) - Except SC contempt
**16. Forests** (Entry 17A - 42nd Amendment) - Shifted from State List
**17. Protection of Wild Animals and Birds** (Entry 17B - 42nd Amendment)
**18. Economic and Social Planning** (Entry 20) - Planning Commission, NITI Aayog
**19. Commercial and Industrial Monopolies** (Entry 21) - Competition Act, MRTP
**20. Trade Unions** (Entry 22) - Labour unions, industrial disputes
**21. Social Security** (Entry 23) - ESI, PF, Welfare schemes
**23. Education** (Entry 25 - 42nd Amendment) - Shifted from State List
**26. Legal Profession** (Entry 26) - Advocates Act, Bar Councils
**29. Population Control and Family Planning** (Entry 20A - 42nd Amendment)
art254Repugnancy: **Art 254**: If Parliament and State law on Concurrent subject conflict → **Repugnancy**
**Rule**: Union law prevails; State law void to extent of repugnancy
**Exception**: If State law reserved for President's assent and he gives assent → State law prevails **in that state**
**BUT**: Parliament can still override by making another law
**Examples**: Criminal law (IPC), Contract Act, Evidence Act - Union laws on Concurrent subjects; States can make supplementary laws
importantPoints: **47 subjects**: Both Centre and States can legislate
**42nd Amendment**: Added/shifted 5 subjects (Education, Forests, Weights & Measures, Wild animals, Justice admin, Population control)
**Major laws**: IPC, CrPC, CPC, Contract Act, Evidence Act - All on Concurrent List
**Taxation**: No taxation entry in Concurrent (except GST after 101st Amendment)
gstEntry: **101st Amendment 2016**: Added Goods and Services Tax (GST) entries
**Concurrent taxation**: Both Centre and States levy GST (CGST + SGST = GST)
**IGST**: Centre levies Integrated GST on inter-state trade
content.examTips: **Concurrent List = 47 subjects**. Both can legislate; **Union law prevails** (Art 254 - repugnancy). Major subjects: Criminal law (IPC, CrPC), Civil law (CPC), Marriage, Contracts, Education, Forests. **42nd Amendment added 5** (Education, Forests, etc.). **101st Amendment added GST**.

provision: **Art 248**: Parliament has **exclusive power** to make laws on **residuary subjects**
**Residuary subjects**: Subjects **not mentioned in any of the 3 Lists**
**Residuary clause**: Shows strong Centre (unitary feature)
**No state legislature power**: States have NO power on residuary subjects
whatAreResiduary: Subjects that were **not anticipated** when Constitution was framed
Subjects that **emerged later** due to technological/social developments
• **Information Technology** - Software, IT industry, cyber laws (IT Act 2000)
• **Cyber crimes** - Hacking, identity theft, online fraud
• **Space technology** - Commercial space activities (beyond atomic energy)
constitutionalBasis: **Art 248(1)**: Parliament can make any law on any matter not enumerated in Concurrent or State List
**Art 248(2)**: Residuary power includes power to make law imposing tax not mentioned in any List
**Exclusive to Parliament**: Unlike USA (residuary with states), Canada (residuary with Centre), India chose Centre (unitary bias)
taxation: **Examples**: Service Tax (before 88th Amendment made it explicit Entry 92B Union List)
After GST (101st Amendment): Residuary taxation less important (most taxes covered)
content.examTips: **Art 248**: Residuary powers with **Parliament** (NOT states) - Shows **strong Centre** (unitary feature). Examples: IT, Internet, Cyber laws, AI, E-commerce, Cryptocurrency. Compare with USA (states have residuary), Canada (Centre like India).

articles.title: Art 249 - Parliament Legislates on State List (National Interest)

provision: **Art 249**: **Rajya Sabha** can authorize Parliament to make laws on **State List** in **national interest**
**Condition**: Rajya Sabha must pass resolution by **2/3rd majority** of members present and voting
**Effect**: Parliament can legislate on that State List subject for **whole of India**
**Duration**: Resolution valid for **1 year**; Can be renewed any number of times (1 year each time)
procedure: **Step 1**: Rajya Sabha passes resolution declaring that it is necessary/expedient in **national interest** that Parliament make laws on specified State List subject
**Step 2**: **2/3rd majority** of RS members present and voting required (special majority)
**Step 3**: Once passed, Parliament (both LS and RS) can make law on that subject
**Step 4**: Law applies to **whole of India** (not just some states)
**Step 5**: Law ceases to have effect after **6 months** after resolution ceases to be in force
whyRajyaSabha: **States' consent**: Through their representatives in RS, states authorize Centre to legislate
**2/3rd majority**: Ensures broad consensus; Not simple majority
**Federal spirit**: States (via RS) voluntarily surrender their exclusive domain to Centre for national interest
nationalInterest: **Not defined**: 'National interest' not defined in Constitution
**Rajya Sabha decides**: RS itself decides what constitutes national interest
**Cannot be challenged**: Courts cannot question RS's determination of national interest (political question)
**Examples**: National emergency, economic crisis, pandemic, war preparation, coordinated national policy needed
examplesOfUse: **Never used extensively**: Art 249 has been used very rarely
**Reason**: Parliament prefers to use other methods (Art 250 - emergency; Art 252 - state consent; Art 253 - treaty)
**Alternative**: Most times, subject is put in Concurrent List via constitutional amendment (like Education, Forests via 42nd Amendment)
limitations: **Only for national interest**: Not for any reason
**Rajya Sabha alone**: Lok Sabha cannot pass such resolution
**2/3rd majority**: High threshold; Difficult to achieve
**Temporary**: Maximum 1 year (renewable); Law ceases after 6 months of resolution expiry
**No permanent transfer**: State's legislative competence not permanently taken away
content.examTips: **Art 249**: **Rajya Sabha** (2/3 majority) can authorize Parliament to legislate on **State List** in **national interest**. Valid for **1 year** (renewable). Law ceases after **6 months** of resolution expiry. Why RS? Represents states (federal spirit). Rarely used in practice.

articles.title: Art 250 - Parliament Legislates on State List (During Emergency)

provision: **Art 250**: During **National Emergency** (Art 352), Parliament can make laws on **any subject in State List**
**No state consent needed**: Parliament can legislate unilaterally
**No special majority**: Ordinary legislative process sufficient
**Effect**: India becomes **unitary** during emergency; Federal structure suspended
whenApplicable: **Only during National Emergency** (Art 352) - War, External aggression, Armed rebellion
**NOT during other emergencies**: Does NOT apply to President's Rule (Art 356) or Financial Emergency (Art 360)
**President's proclamation**: Must be in force; Once emergency revoked, Art 250 power ceases
duration: **While emergency continues**: Parliament can legislate throughout emergency period
**After emergency ends**: Law continues for **6 months** after emergency proclamation ceases
**After 6 months**: Law becomes inoperative (unless extended by Parliament or State Legislature adopts it)
**No automatic repeal**: Law doesn't automatically become void; Just ceases to have effect
scopeOfPower: **Any subject**: Parliament can legislate on ANY subject in State List (no limitations)
**All states**: Law applies to all states (not limited to particular state)
**Override state laws**: Parliament's law on State List overrides state laws
**Concurrent-like**: State List temporarily becomes like Concurrent List (both can legislate, but Union prevails)
examples: **During 1962 Emergency** (China war): Parliament made laws on State subjects
**During 1971 Emergency** (Bangladesh war): Centre controlled many state subjects
**During 1975-77 Emergency**: Parliament extensively legislated on State List subjects (authoritarian period)
implications: **Federal → Unitary**: India's federal character suspended during emergency
**Strong Centre**: Shows strong central control in crisis
**State autonomy lost**: States lose exclusive legislative competence
**Temporary measure**: Designed for crisis; Not permanent
content.examTips: **Art 250**: During **National Emergency** (Art 352), Parliament can legislate on **State List**. No state consent needed. Law continues for **6 months** after emergency ends. Shows **Federal → Unitary** transformation during emergency. NOT applicable to Art 356, 360.

articles.title: Art 252 - Parliament Legislates with State Consent

provision: **Art 252**: If **two or more states** consent, Parliament can make law on **State List** subject for those states
**State resolution**: State Legislature must pass resolution requesting Parliament to legislate
**Voluntary**: States voluntarily surrender their legislative competence to Parliament
**Effect**: Parliament's law applies only to **consenting states** (not all India)
procedure: **Step 1**: Two or more State Legislatures pass **resolutions** requesting Parliament to make law on specified State List subject
**Step 2**: Parliament makes law; Law applies to **consenting states only**
**Step 3**: Other states can **adopt later**: Any other state can pass resolution to adopt the law (law then applies to that state too)
**Step 4**: **No withdrawal**: Once state consents, it **cannot withdraw** consent; Irreversible
**Step 5**: Parliament can **amend or repeal**: Only Parliament can amend/repeal (states cannot)
whyUsed: **Uniform law desired**: When states want uniform law on a subject (e.g., inter-state coordination needed)
**State lacks expertise**: State may lack resources/expertise to draft complex legislation
**Inter-state uniformity**: Subjects requiring uniformity across states (but not national issue, so Art 249 not applicable)
**Cooperative federalism**: Example of cooperative federalism in action
examples: **Wildlife Protection Act 1972**: Many states requested Parliament to legislate (before Forests moved to Concurrent List)
**Water and Air Pollution Acts**: Before Environment subjects in Concurrent
**Inter-state River Water Disputes**: States consent to Parliament making law
**Prize Competitions Act 1955**: States requested uniform law on lotteries, prize competitions
limitations: **No withdrawal**: State cannot withdraw once consent given
**Parliament's control**: Only Parliament can amend/repeal (state has no control)
**Limited applicability**: Applies only to consenting states (not all India)
**Two states minimum**: At least two states must request; Single state cannot invoke Art 252
comparison: **Art 249**: National interest, Rajya Sabha 2/3 majority, 1 year validity, All India → **Temporary**
**Art 252**: State consent, No special majority, Permanent until repealed, Consenting states only → **Permanent**
**Art 250**: Emergency, No consent, 6 months after emergency, All India → **Crisis measure**
content.examTips: **Art 252**: If **2+ states consent**, Parliament can legislate on **State List**. **Permanent** (unlike Art 249 - temporary). State **cannot withdraw**. Only Parliament can amend/repeal. Applies only to **consenting states**. Example: Wildlife Protection Act. Shows **cooperative federalism**.

provision: **Art 253**: Parliament can make law on **any subject** (including State List) to implement **international treaty/agreement**
**No state consent needed**: Parliament's exclusive power; States cannot refuse
**Overrides federal distribution**: Treaty obligation overrides federal division of powers
**Effect**: India can fulfill international commitments even if subject in State List
rationale: **International obligations**: India must honor treaty commitments
**Single voice**: India speaks as one nation internationally; Cannot say 'state subject, Centre cannot implement'
**Sovereignty**: Treaty-making power with Union (Entry 14 Union List - Foreign affairs)
**Federal limitation**: Federal division of powers should not prevent fulfilling international obligations
scopeOfPower: **Any treaty**: Bilateral, multilateral, conventions, international agreements
**Any subject**: Even if subject in State List, Parliament can legislate
**No judicial review of necessity**: Courts cannot question whether law is necessary for treaty implementation
**Wide interpretation**: Courts have given wide interpretation to Art 253; Liberal approach
examples: **TRIPS Agreement** (WTO): Patent laws, Copyright laws - Implemented via Parliament laws (even though Concurrent subject)
**UNCLOS** (UN Convention on Law of Sea): Maritime zones - Parliament law
**Montreal Protocol**: Ozone layer protection - Environment laws by Parliament
**CITES**: Wildlife protection - Parliament laws on state subjects
**ILO Conventions**: Labour laws - Parliament implementing ILO conventions
importantCases: **Maganbhai Ishwarbhai Patel v Union (1969)**: SC upheld Parliament's power under Art 253 to legislate on State List subject for implementing treaty
**Reasoning**: Treaty obligations must be fulfilled; Federal division cannot be excuse for non-performance
**Wide scope**: Art 253 gives Parliament wide power; Not limited to specific subjects
limitations: **Genuine treaty**: Must be genuine international treaty/agreement (not domestic matter disguised as treaty)
**Good faith**: Centre cannot misuse by making sham treaties to encroach on State List
**Basic Structure**: Cannot violate basic structure of Constitution (federalism is basic structure)
content.examTips: **Art 253**: Parliament can legislate on **any subject** (including State List) to implement **international treaty**. No state consent needed. Shows **international obligations > federal division**. Examples: TRIPS, ILO conventions, UNCLOS. **Maganbhai case** upheld. Prevents federal excuse for treaty non-performance.

provision: **Art 254**: If Parliament and State law on **Concurrent List** subject conflict → **Repugnancy**
**General rule**: **Union law prevails**; State law void to extent of repugnancy
**Exception**: If State law **reserved for President's assent** and President gives assent → State law prevails **in that state**
**Parliamentary override**: Parliament can still override by making fresh law
whenRepugnancyArises: **Direct conflict**: Both laws cannot operate together; Mutually contradictory provisions
**Occupy same field**: Both laws cover same subject matter; Cannot coexist
• Union law allows something; State law prohibits same thing
• Union law prescribes one procedure; State law prescribes different procedure
• Union law gives certain rights; State law denies those rights
testOfRepugnancy: **Test 1**: Is there **direct collision**? (Both laws say opposite things)
**Test 2**: Do both laws **occupy same field**? (Both regulate same thing comprehensively)
**Test 3**: Does State law take away what Union law gives? (State law nullifies Union law)
**If YES to any**: Repugnancy exists → Union law prevails
art254Exception: **State law reserved for President**: State Governor reserves State law for President's consideration (Art 200, 201)
**President gives assent**: President approves reserved State law
**Effect**: State law prevails **in that state** despite repugnancy with Union law
**BUT**: Parliament can override anytime by making fresh law on same subject
importantCases: **Deep Chand v State of UP (1959)**: SC defined repugnancy - Direct conflict or occupy same field
**M Karunanidhi v Union (1979)**: SC held state law on prevention of disqualification conflicted with Parliament's law; State law void
**Tika Ramji v State of UP (1956)**: UP law conflicted with Essential Commodities Act (Union law); State law void to extent of repugnancy
**Zaverbhai v State of Bombay (1954)**: Bombay law on industrial disputes conflicted with Industrial Disputes Act (Union); Bombay law void
implications: **Union supremacy**: Shows Centre's dominance even on Concurrent List (unitary feature)
**State law subordinate**: State laws on Concurrent subject always vulnerable
**Limited state autonomy**: States' concurrent power heavily constrained
**Parliamentary override**: Even President-assented state law can be overridden by Parliament
content.examTips: **Art 254**: Repugnancy on **Concurrent List** → **Union law prevails**. Test: Direct conflict OR Occupy same field. **Exception**: State law reserved for President + President's assent → State law prevails in that state (BUT Parliament can override). Shows **Union supremacy** (unitary feature). **Deep Chand case** - Test of repugnancy.

articles.title: Governor's Power of Reservation - Centre's Control Mechanism

provision: **Art 200**: Governor can **reserve** State Bill for President's consideration (instead of giving assent)
**Art 201**: President may give assent, withhold assent, or return Bill (except Money Bill)
**Centre's control**: Indirect control over State legislation via Governor (Centre's agent)
**Effect**: State Bill cannot become law without President's approval (if reserved)
whenGovernorReserves: **Mandatory reservation**: Constitution/law requires reservation for certain types of Bills
**Discretionary reservation**: Governor may reserve in his discretion
• Bills conflicting with Union laws on Concurrent subjects
presidentsOptions: **Option 2**: Withhold assent → Bill dies (cannot become law)
**Option 3**: Return Bill (except Money Bill) with message → State Legislature reconsiders → If passed again, Governor must present to President again (President's decision final)
**No time limit**: President can take indefinite time (pocket veto possible)
centreControlMechanism: **Governor is Centre's agent**: Appointed by President (Art 155); Removable by President
**Centre guides Governor**: Through informal channels, Centre can guide Governor to reserve Bills
**Indirect control**: Centre cannot directly veto State laws; But through Governor and reservation, Centre exercises control
**Examples**: Governor reserved State Bills conflicting with Union policy (land reforms, APMC reforms, etc.)
criticism: **Governor's partisanship**: Governor may reserve Bills for political reasons (if Centre and State have different parties)
**Pocket veto**: President can delay indefinitely (no time limit for decision)
**Sarkaria Commission**: Recommended guidelines for reservation; Avoid political misuse
content.examTips: **Art 200-201**: Governor can **reserve** State Bill for President. President may **assent, withhold, or return** (except Money Bill). Centre's **indirect control** over State legislation. Governor = Centre's agent. Shows **unitary feature**. Criticism: Undermines federalism, partisanship, pocket veto.

data.summary: **Centre-State Legislative Relations**: Parliament can legislate on **Union List (97) + Concurrent List (47) + Residuary** (Art 246, 248). States can legislate on **State List (61) + Concurrent (47)**. **Concurrent conflict** → Union law prevails (Art 254 - repugnancy). **Parliament can invade State List**: (1) Art 249 - Rajya Sabha 2/3 majority, national interest, 1 year; (2) Art 250 - During emergency; (3) Art 252 - State consent (2+ states), permanent; (4) Art 253 - International treaty. **Centre's control**: Governor reservation (Art 200-201), Art 254 repugnancy. Shows **strong Centre** (unitary features dominate). **42nd Amendment** shifted 5 subjects from State to Concurrent (centralization). **101st Amendment** added GST (concurrent taxation).
